did.abstract: Family correspondence of Solomon Howe and his wife, Mary, and their children. Included are letters, 1819, from Jebediah Howe, concerning his stereotype foundry in New York City; letters, 1819-1821, from Milton Howe, who conducted a school in Richmond County, Va., giving some description of the country and his impressions of the people; letters from Celia Babbett, describing a journey to Orangeville, N.Y., and customs in western New York; and miscellaneous letters concerning New Englanders' reactions to the South, the depression following the panic of 1819, crops, commodity prices, and family matters.
